spans.text: Tomori began to rummage through a stack of neatly arranged papers, and soon pulled out one and handed it to Taki, who was following behind her.
This is my previous draft, what does Taki think?
(...Is this what a draft should look like?)
There is almost nothing here that can be called a story. The paper is mostly filled with words: single words, words connected together, words covered in ink, words circled again and again...
(Dream, cicada wing, snow, motive, mouthparts, scorching heat, towel, hardened soil...)
As if to show its importance, a word occupied the upper left corner of the paper in a larger font - "Living."

Next to it was a question mark of the same size, and then both were smeared back and forth by the pen tip. Tomori had crossed it out before, but at the site of this word's remains, she rewrote it in a smaller font: Living?
Many questions unfolded in Taki Shiina's mind with the rebirth of this word.
(Is the cicada alive? How can it live? Why live?)

These questions had no answers, so she went on to look for longer sentences. They were scattered abruptly among the words, separated by a great distance from each other—whether on paper or in the story.

The cicada finally found its favorite tree root. The root of this old tree, old enough to be called such, still had tiny holes left by other cicadas when they fed. When it woke up, it could have a full meal.
The cicada woke up from the tree hole, and it shouted around, "Is anyone there?!" "Hello?", but there was no response. The wind at the entrance of the hole was much colder than when it fell asleep.
Perhaps it could hibernate? It had never tried to fall asleep in the summer, and was a little worried that it would wake up halfway.
(The cicada decided to "hibernate" until winter?)
I can roughly imagine the atmosphere of the story. Um, I'm very curious about the subsequent development.
But it hasn't pieced together a complete beginning yet.
Why would the cicada want to see winter, and why would it decide to do this "go see winter" thing?
Because...
Because it had never seen winter? Because a certain character told it about winter and made it curious? Or because winter was just there?
These reasons can't be considered wrong, but they are not enough to motivate it to make such an important decision that is completely different from its usual life.
But what if one day it wakes up and suddenly realizes that it has changed?
Like white pepper appearing in the usual soup.
Like the usual sweet tamagoyaki turning salty.
As autumn approached, it found that its vitality seemed to be weakening day by day.
She felt her fixed heartbeat finally stop suddenly. Her expression must be changing drastically now.
She secretly looked at Tomori, hoping she hadn't noticed, but Tomori was just staring at her feet, seemingly thinking about how to continue the story.
If such a sudden event makes it realize that it "needs to start doing something," the meaning of life will seem clearer, right?
Um...isn't it a little difficult to understand without specific plot points?
Tomori picked up the draft paper.
Let's start by talking about the cicada's curiosity about winter. Once upon a time, there was a cicada...
Once upon a time, there was a cicada. Unlike the cicadas in everyone's impression that echoed each other and resounded throughout the entire forest, it was a lonely cicada.
When it broke out of the soil and sang its first song in life, it did not hear the accompaniment and duet of its companions. The surroundings were silent.

This fact did not bother the cicada for long, because the cicada finally saw the world outside the soil, which filled its small abdomen with excitement and fiery emotions. It had to sing out all these unspent passions with songs.
It just kept singing like this, and the song finally waited for accompaniment, a strange tune, incomprehensible, but after all, it was singing along with it.
The cicada followed the sound to get to know the other party.
This fellow with stout hind legs called himself Cricket.

Summer was so long that a song could not be finished even when sung over and over again. They first competed to sing louder, and when they were tired, they took turns. When they were even more tired, they sat down to rest and chatted together.

Cricket was very talkative. It claimed to have seen the world earlier than the cicada, so of course it knew more. From the prosperity of the city to the ecology of the countryside, it never stopped talking once it started. The stringed instruments and plectrums on its wings collided quickly, making the sound of accompaniment.

However, what Cricket liked to talk about most were things that had not happened but were about to happen, from the rain that would fall in a few hours to the autumn and winter that would come after a long, long time. Seasons were its favorite topic.
Autumn is cool, and the sun is so far away from the grass that it definitely can't find anything to eat. It's so hungry that it doesn't even have the strength to bask in the sun.
The leaves will also become thin and brittle. But anyway, I don't like to eat them, they're too dry, like the paper skins that humans eat, there's no juice.
Cicadas can't chew things like grasshoppers, they mostly live by sucking the sap of trees, so they can't taste what paper skins taste like, but it doesn't like dry things either.
Summer is still good.
It's always better than winter.
The topic slid to a more distant point on the timeline. Winter was even more mysterious than autumn.

Before the long-lived insects in the group weaken, they will write down the changes at the beginning of autumn on the trees. Some of the vanguards who first stick their heads out of the soil every year can also grasp the tail of spring.
But the cicada had never seen these kinds of companions. It didn't know much about spring and autumn, let alone winter.
What is winter like?
Winter is the season after autumn. All the leaves will fall off, there will be nothing to eat, and there will be snow.
What is snow?
Snow is something that is very cold and very white.
Is it colder than autumn?
It's colder than autumn, and it will make the whole world its white.
The cicada still wanted to give more examples to compare snow to in order to understand its whiteness, but it was interrupted by the other party's predictability. Cricket put on a profound look.
It's whiter than anything you can imagine. All white things become ashamed of themselves and turn into black ink in front of it.
The cicada was almost dizzy. What is the white that is whiter than anything you can imagine? How black is ink?
Cricket saw that the other party was already overwhelmed by its erudition, and waved its antennae triumphantly.
You'll understand when you see the snow!
So it sang loudly again.
Tomori raised her head, and the pen that was quickly recording the key points as she spoke also stopped.
Does Taki know why Cricket didn't continue?
(Because it was satisfied and complacent? No, it shouldn't be.)
I remember Cricket's lifespan...
That's right, Cricket is also known as the three-season insect. It has never really seen winter, let alone snow, so it doesn't actually know how to describe it.
Taki didn't know how to continue. Should she say that Cricket was showing off and describing things it hadn't seen, or that the cicada became interested in snow just because of this sentence?
Fortunately, Tomori started to continue the story.
But the cicada didn't know that Cricket had never seen snow either. In this summer that seemed too long because of the heat, it asked Cricket questions about snow again and again.
Besides knowing that snow was white and cold, it also knew that snow was thick and heavy, and would tightly wrap everything it covered, unaffected by the cold from the outside world.

It knew that snow was good: "Snow is a good omen for a bumper year." Cricket was eloquent in praising the bumper year, so snow, as an envoy announcing the arrival of the bumper year, should be just as good.
But the cicada had never seen snow.
"You'll understand when you see the snow!" It would often think of this sentence, and Cricket's description planted a seed of expectation in its heart.
But things changed one day...
The cicada realized it was going to die.
Yes, the cicada realized it was going to die. It became more and more sleepy, ate less and less, and occasionally woke up suddenly in the middle of the night, feeling an urgent urge to sing.
It also wondered if this was the effect of the low air pressure before the arrival of autumn, until one time...
Um, when it was eating, it lost its grip on the tree trunk and suddenly fell from the tree?
Tomori lowered her head and drew another circle on the draft she had just written.
I still have to think about the events here. In short, an unknown future that it had not envisioned was approaching it faster than winter.
But the key is the psychological change after it knows this. Taki, what do you think the cicada would want to do at this time?
I...it would definitely have a buffer period at first, disbelief, verification, and then sadness.
When it realizes that its plan to see winter is difficult to achieve, it should choose to do some important things.
Taki pointed to the sentence Tomori had written on the paper before.
I think you can start here—the cicada is about to hibernate.
"Perhaps I can hibernate?"

Perhaps I can hibernate. It had never tried to fall asleep in the summer, and was a little worried that it would wake up halfway. But it had been sleeping more and more lately, often waking up late at night after a nap.
It should be fine.
It looked around at the preparations it had made: food to eat after waking up, a safe and warm place to live, and now the last step.
It pushed open Cricket's door, and the owner of the room was obviously a little surprised by its arrival.
I haven't heard your song lately, I thought...
I'm going to prepare for hibernation.
The cicada briefly introduced its recent situation and decision: everything is not going well, so I'll take a nap.
Cricket listened in silence for a long time, and finally took out a small leaf from the depths of the room.
This is the hibernation address I chose. If you see snow, you can bring it over to find me.
So it started its hibernation with this leaf.
It was a black and deep dream, like returning to the soil. For the song it would sing after it emerged from the soil, it had stayed in the dark and humid soil for an uncountable amount of time.

And now this summer song has reached its end. It doesn't know whether to sing in winter. Cricket said that it will also hibernate, and its audience is already very few. If it doesn't create in its dreams, what should it dream about during this time?
This question eventually fell into that dark dream, doubts fell into it, tunes fell into it, thoughts fell into it, and even the cicada itself was about to fall into it.
It slept very deeply, and for a moment it even thought it would never wake up again. But it still has snow to see!
So the cicada struggled to roll its body and vibrate its wings, so the darkness was shaken off by the thin cicada wings like rain on a cloudy day.
Then it felt cold. It rolled out of its tree hole in its sleep, and now there was only a pure white around it.
So this is snow.

The cicada even forgot to feel joy at first. What a magical sight this is. The original world is divided into two, one floating on the surface, white and harmonious, and the other hidden deep down, mysterious and familiar.

The cicada quietly lay on the snow, and the snow under its feet gradually melted. This familiar touch of the soil brought it back to the world before the snowfall, reminding it that in that world, it had a promise.
The road after the snow was not easy to walk, and it took the cicada a long time to reach the tree hole pointed to by the leaf.

Cricket was lying in a pile of leaves that had already turned yellow and dry. These leaves should be the hibernation food it had stored, but they should no longer be delicious. The cicada felt a pang of regret.
Taki was completely immersed in the atmosphere of the fairy tale, but Tomori stopped there and began to think about the floor with her hands against her forehead.
Tomori seemed to be still thinking about how to arrange the following plot, but she already had a rough ending.
Taki took over the story and continued to tell it.
It gently shook the other party, but Cricket seemed to be sleeping soundly and did not wake up.
Tomori looked up at Taki.
"Maybe it's also hibernating?" the cicada thought, "It's a pity to miss this snow."
But fortunately it can still sing, fortunately it can still sing.
The white snow will melt after winter, but the songs can continue to spread.
If it wants to, it can continue to sing next summer.
At that time, it can also tell the other party what it saw snow like and how it felt at the time.
Taki Shiina swallowed and found that telling stories was not as simple as she thought.
Words reflect the author's past experiences and current state of mind. She unconsciously dyed the story with her own colors.
But she continued to tell it.
The cicada tore off a dry leaf and drew melodies and rhythms on it.
The snow fell bigger and bigger. Just when the snow was about to completely bury the entrance of the cave, it left the last note on the somewhat dry leaf with that thin bit of light.
"It turns out that there really is a warm feeling in the snow." the cicada thought.
It also began to feel sleepy, put the written score next to Cricket, so that the other party could see it as soon as it finished hibernating.
It yawned again, humming its tune softly.
"Let's take another nap." it thought.
......The story ends here.
She concluded somewhat dejectedly, trying to make the ending look less pessimistic with an abrupt ending.
Tomori nodded thoughtfully, and shook her head rarely.
Wouldn't it...not be like a fairy tale?
The cicada has seen winter, seen the white snow, and it has done what it wanted to do most.
Why does it need to write songs to prove to Cricket that it has seen it?
Tomori...what kind of ending would you write?
I haven't thought of it yet.
Tomori said this sentence with almost no resistance. The openness after overcoming the key problem made her answer very quickly.
But I think, in the story of a fairy tale, the cicada can live to winter, why can't the cricket wake up from a long hibernation?
How about letting the cicada wake up the hibernating cricket and let it get up to see the snow?
Or the cicada thinks that the other party is frozen, and recalls the story between them to the sleeping cricket?
"This is the rain-shielding leaf you gave me, this is the shard of glass you picked up that can refract seven colors of light..."
"This is the snow I just picked up. If you sleep for a whole winter, it will melt."
Cricket was awakened by the cicada's noisy movements like moving house, and didn't know whether to continue pretending to sleep.
Eh?
Taki finally broke away from the heavy atmosphere of the story and asked a subconscious question about this somewhat unconventional ending.
Just treat it as the magic of friendship?
I still want to write a gentler ending.
Tomori smiled a little embarrassedly.
When I originally joined Cricket, I wanted to write a story about a short life, teaching children to cherish the good times.
But what about after the good times? When the cicada realizes that its life is coming to an end, it puts all its energy into preparing to realize its wish.

Now that this wish has been fulfilled, the cicada will also have some new expectations, right? See the appearance of all things recovering with Cricket next year, and even feel the golden autumn after the snow, which represents the harvest of the coming year.
Because as long as life remains, the story will continue.
Even if you get lost, you will continue to move forward, and you will not stop after seeing the snow—sure enough, I still want to tell a story about this kind of theme.
Tomori held the pen with both hands, her eyes as gentle as if she was looking at her pebble collection.
However, I think the ending that Taki said is also very good.
If the cicada thinks that the music is its pursuit...
But, that is Taki's story...If you take it to the publisher, the royalties may have to be split with Taki.
Haha, just put my name after Tomori's.
The two smiled at each other, and the serious atmosphere of wanting to come up with a suitable theme for the fairy tale was also dispelled by this harmless joke.
Tomori closed her pen and neatly stored the newly written draft.
Thank you, Taki.
You're welcome! I also...I also gained a lot.
Tomori rarely called Taki by her first name, which was enough to prove Tomori's satisfaction with this story, but Taki was still struggling with that ending.
(Use memories and objects with companions to bring Cricket back to life?)
(It sounds more like a good ending than composing music...It's a pity that it only exists in fairy tales.)
"But I think, in the story of a fairy tale, the cicada can live to winter, why can't the cricket wake up from a long hibernation?"
A small rumbling sound from her stomach interrupted her thoughts.
Oh no, the dishes are probably cold.
Tomori, if there is a chance, I will make it for you next time.
Yeah! I'm looking forward to it.
